Tldr version:  You don’t need money to win in this game. It is possible to finish in the top 20 each season without spending money but it takes some time and experience. The more you play, the better you will be because your cards will be getting stronger. The game doesn’t require “skill” but “strategy”. You will choose your cards based on how they compliment yours and how to counter your opponent’s but you won’t be “active” in the battle taking more of a spectator role. The single player it’s short. The multiplayer it’s where everyone is. It’s fun, it’s free, you should check it out.  Now for a more extensive review:  P2W or not P2W?  Ignore the people whining about being impossible for a free player to win often in this game, as you can see by the time they spent on the game, they simply didn’t give the game a chance and judged it in a superficial way. I am a free player. I have never spent a single cent on this game. And I have an 85% win ratio on Pro Matches, I have finished on TOP 20 to get the legendary card twice and I expect to do it again in the future.  With all that said, there is a clear advantage for whoever “farm” the missions day by day and have played the game for a long time or for people that “pay” money to get the gems the easy way at the beginning of the game.  The good news is that if someone pays anything less than 50 dollars then they are just getting exactly the same thing you can get by simply playing the game for a few weeks or months. So after a few months your account will be strong enough that you won’t even care about people spending 50 or even 100 dollars to become stronger.   The problem comes with the people that spend over 100 dollars in the game and not just that but over 400 or 500. There are cards that cost 180 dollars and are the strongest in the game, whoever get those cards will have a definitive advantage against pretty much 99% of the players. But then again, those guys spent 500 dollars on a free to play card game. It sounds that the problem here it’s not the game but those people that can’t control themselves.  The truth is, if they couldn’t sell you gems for you to buy cards faster, then they wouldn’t have any means to earn money in the game and would have to make it a pay to play game. Nobody it’s going to buy “skins” or other “items” on a card game. The design of these card games it’s so basic that it has to affect the gameplay in order to interest people into buying.  So, in the end, the P2W aspect in the game exist. But at the same time it doesn’t affect you from performing well if you are a free player, you can have an 80% win ratio like me without spending money and you can also get the legendary card reward by finishing top 20 on ladder which is pretty much the most valuable reward to achieve in the game.  Multiplayer  It’s a different kind of game. It’s designed for mobiles and thus it doesn’t ask for a lot of activity on your part. It’s not a game about skill, it’s a game about strategy.   You have missions to do every day. They all consist on win or play several matches pretty much in all the modes and then collect the reward. You can play for coins or ladder. Coins are used to buy packs to get cards and in ladder your results will end up on a leaderboard and at the end of each season you will get rewards based on your position.   You can also join guilds. Guilds compete against each other in a special season. At the end of this season all the guilds get rewards based on the position they finished on the leaderboard. There is a special chat for guilds member whom you can talk with but that's the only real special thing they have. There it’s nothing special you do in a guild beside this, the guild points are all based on activity. So as long as you play, you are helping your guild and at season end, your guild will help you with those rewards.  All modes consist pretty much on picking cards from you collection and then watching the battle take place against your opponent cards. You cannot participate in the battle which is something that some people complain about. But again, this isn’t a game of skill but strategy. With experience it’s very easy to see how the battle it’s going to turn out just by looking at your cards and your opponents before the battle actually takes place.  There are 3 modes in multiplayer:   Quick Mode: You pick a deck of 6 cards from you collection and you are paired randomly against another player. It’s basically a complex rock, paper and scissor type of game. But it’s not all about luck, I have an 80% win ratio there instead of just 50%. Because you shouldn’t simply pick cards randomly. You need to look for an efficient deck or create your own deck if you think it could be effective. There is a matchmaking system based on cards rarities and levels to avoid “expensive” cards to dominate the mode, so your strongest cards may no guarantee better results. This mode it’s usually played to “farm” coins and matches played for the missions.  Pro Mode: This it’s the most interesting mode in the game in my opinion. It’s a 6 card battle like Quick mode but this time you will only pick 2 and you will get paired with someone. Then in the second turn you can pick another 2 but the smart thing to do, it’s to choose those cards based not only on your first 2 cards but also on your opponents first 2. You need to counter and sometimes you can see where he is going and how his deck will look like just by seeing his first 2 cards. Finally on the third turn you will choose your last 2 cards, this time already knowing 4 of your opponent 6 cards. After this, the battle begins.  Hardcore Mode: This mode it’s basically 3 quick modes all put together one after the other. There is strategy here also but there not too much countering and a lot more “risky blind betting” or simply trying to anticipate which kind of deck your opponent will use next. When your first deck wins, it will stay and fight (wounded as it is) your opponent next deck, that’s why knowing how to counter decks it’s important and anticipating your opponent can be the difference of the fight in this mode more than the other.   In the end, I do not recommend Hardcore Mode for free players because I feel that the mode is too unbalanced in favor of people that spends above 100 dollars in this game. I only play quick mode because the matchmaking makes my deck be very efficient and Pro Mode where I feel that the game gives me a fair chance to beat almost everyone if I play my cards right.  Single Player:  There is a campaign in the game. They reward you with coins, rubies diamonds and some valuable cards. But it’s not too extensive and it’s mostly a stepping stone to prepare you for multiplayer.  Problems:  The biggest problem it has right now it’s the lack of updates. The game it’s fun and if you haven’t played it I suggest you  to try it out but after a while the game starts to feel repetitive because the devs haven’t released new cards in a very long time.

Let me preface this really quickly. IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR AN ACTIVE CARD GAME, THIS IS NOT THE GAME FOR YOU.  ECB is a passive card game where you construct a field and, based on the traits of the cards you use, automatically fight other decks.  There is an obvious PayToWin path, but seeing past negative reviews, most issues coming from here stem from players not seeing other option or have been changed for the better, which is good in my book.  From what I've experienced so far, there is definitely a grind to get a free experience from this game. And that's perfectly acceptable compared to other free online TCG/CCG games where there is an equivalent grind. And ECB compensates heavily for that early on with a very extensive campain mode that treats it as a somewhat strategic puzzler.

This game is actually fun and not pay to win if you read and have patience. Most Americans are lazy, don't read and want things to be easy. At first I was losing because I was just spamming random cards with the most stars. After losing a PVP match to someone who used all 1 star cards, I knew there had to be some strategy invovled. Which there is, actually TONS of strategy but a decent amount of reading invovled since there are so many options to counter other players cards.   It's really not pay to win if you know what you are doing. Like I said, you have to read the cards to see what they counter. I learned enhancing Ice Elementals to level 30 is amazing in PVP. Which is a 1 star card but owns and can control an entire game.  The game has been around since 2013, so other players have a card advantage and obviously have been getting the day 30 card rewards, which are 4 star cards. If you keep playing you will eventually get free cards that are really good. Just don't expect to be pro in 2 hours like most of these reviews.   The playerbase averages at about 350ish playing at all times. So you will always have someone to fight in PVP. READ your opponents cards to see why they are chosing them. This game is NOT just about hit points and health points. The daily mission rewards are good, the packs for free currency helps build your collection and login rewards are good.  Tips: -Buy the 998 coin packs first. (about 5 or 6) -Then start to buy the 2498 coin packs. -Enhance Ice Elementals to level 30. -READ the cards and do the tutorial because there are A LOT of rules in this game.

I'm rather astounded by the negative reviews for this game. Personally I found it to be one of the few TCGs on Steam that have kept my attention for a decent amount of time. It's got great content as far as I'm concerned, it's very unlike the other titles.  Noteable features over other~   * Great linear progression - Introduction to different features isn't shown until unlocked, but core content is covered. You can enhance cards, level your character, etc.   * Superior strategy and planning - Each campaign level requires you to analyze the enemy's deck, sort through your own, and then cross your fingers that the monsters, abilities, and supporting spells you've chosen are a working strategy against your opponent.   * Quality over quantity - Each match is fairly fast-paced and the number of cards used per battle is 6 [unless I'm mistaken]  * The individual card's abilties are ridiculously unique, and each card in your deck is useful for a different situation  based on its specific capabilities and stats.   * Unique and quality artwork - None of the artwork or UI is reused or stolen from other games. The style is particularly detailed and gorgeous in my opinion. It's a great moderation between some of the other examples that are too cartoonish or hardcore. There is great variety, and another aspect of note is that portraits of women characters are anatomically correct. Fan servicing is tastefully so, and it's realistic anatomically correct and variable.   * Fast load, solid UI, stable framerate, no noteable bugs, stable build.  --- Overall I think it's a great side-game that's fun to play for decent periods of time. It's a solid competitor against the alternatives, and I highly recommend at least trying it. I can only hope y'all enjoy as it as much as I have!
